game_description: Early Access Experience the thrill of downhill mountain biking like never before in Downhill Bike, the latest VR game from Nomad Monkey. Get ready to ride through scenic landscapes, tackle challenging terrain, and feel the rush of adrenaline as you race against the clock to reach the finish line. With intuitive controls and immersive graphics, Downhill Bike lets you fully immerse yourself in the world of mountain biking. Take on steep descents, sharp turns, and jumps as you navigate through each level. With multiple levels to unlock and explore, there's always a new challenge waiting for you. Whether you're a seasoned biker or new to the sport, Downhill Bike offers an exciting and realistic experience that will keep you coming back for more. So what are you waiting for? Grab your headset, hop on your virtual bike, and start your ride today! Please comment and give us feedback so we can improve the game and implement new worlds for the full version release.
review_1: If you are a fan of mountain biking, this is an amazing VR experience. Downhill Bike simulates riding a mountain bike down a rugged path. Become one with nature and conker that hill. The controls in Downhill Bike feel great, just like holding onto a set of handle bars. The bike give you a great feel of being on a bike. I even found myself standing up time to time when starting to peddle or bunny hopping. This is a free demo on SideQuestVR and I would highly recomene3d trying it out. Bike fans will love this one. Watch my preview here, https://youtu.be/Ow_11rBjjGM
review_2: I actually like this game I was looking for a dirt bike game but then I came across this downloaded it and it was super!cool and I don’t play it much anymore because I found a good dirt bike game but I would recommend this game to mountain bike people.
review_3: I miss rideing my bike and this is the right game if you want to try it out and you miss it bye
review_4: looking around just doesn’t feel as right, the 6° of freedom are limited in this game… Almost made me keep it, but the limiting factor of freedom doesn't feel "natural"
